item.title: Diplomacy | Spanish MNE visit announced this week
item.description: The Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, José Manuel Albares, will make an official visit to China between today and tomorrow, at the invitation of his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, Chinese diplomacy announced yesterday. In a statement, Chinese diplomacy highlighted the “close exchanges” between Beijing and Madrid and classified Spain as “an important strategic partner in Europe”. Ministry spokesman Lin Jian expressed confidence that Albares' visit “will contribute to strengthening bilateral cooperation”, highlighting that the two countries “maintain high-level contacts”, with political trust “being consolidated” and practical cooperation that “has produced fruitful results”, promoting “the economic development and well-being of the populations of both countries”. Lin recalled that this year marks the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Spain, stressing that the move of the head of Spanish diplomacy will allow “to deepen mutual understanding and support” and “boost the high-level development” of the bilateral relationship. According to the spokesperson, Albares' meetings with Chinese leaders will address “bilateral relations and international and regional issues of common interest”. José Manuel Albares' visit comes six months after Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez's trip to China in April, during which he met with Chinese President Xi Jinping. On that occasion, Sánchez described China as an “indispensable partner to face global challenges” and defended the deepening of relations both bilaterally and within the European framework. Chinese diplomacy then classified Sánchez's visit as “a success”, which demonstrated “the determination of both parties to expand their ties”.

item.title: DSAJ | Digital notary services launched
item.description: Digital notary services were launched yesterday by the Directorate of Justice Affairs Services (DSAJ), in a process that will be phased. According to a statement, the services concern four areas, namely deeds, endorsements, online requests for notary services and the provision of an electronic platform for registration requests to be used by private notaries. Yesterday, the 2nd Notary's Office launched the electronic deeds service, extending this service to the first notary's office, the Islands' Notary's Office and private notaries. According to DSAJ, this service “allows the collection, electronically, of the signatures of all grantors, in which the qualified electronic signature of the notary will be placed” in order to prevent “the tampering of documents and ensure their authenticity”. Also yesterday, the electronic endorsement service was launched “which applies to all electronic and paper deeds, as long as the respective digital images have been filed in the Notary System”. Next December, notary offices will begin accepting online requests for notary services, and residents can use the Macau Single Account platform to request services relating to purchase and sale deeds, or the creation of property mortgages, powers of attorney and authenticated documents (authentication terms). DSAJ also provides an online platform for private notaries to process land and commercial registration requests.

item.title: 929 Challenge | More than 400 Chinese and Portuguese-speaking teams
item.description: The online bootcamp of the 929 Challenge in Macau began yesterday, having attracted more than 400 teams and startups from China and Portuguese-speaking countries, an increase of more than 25 percent compared to 2024, the organization highlighted. The last edition of the competition for startups from China and Portuguese-speaking countries had recorded a maximum, with more than 1,600 participants in more than 320 teams. “This growing interest reflects the strengthening of connections between Portuguese-speaking countries and China's innovation ecosystems, progress that we are grateful to witness through continuous collaboration and shared learning between regions”, highlighted the organization, on the social network Instagram. Since yesterday and for two weeks, the 402 teams registered in the fifth edition will participate every day, in an online bootcamp from 7:00 pm to 9:00 pm. Until October 11th, the teams will have a series of lectures, mentoring sessions and workshops “designed to help teams shape, validate and strengthen sustainable business models”. The best 16 plans – eight from companies and eight from university students – will have 10 minutes to convince the 929 Challenge jury and potential investors in the final, on November 30th. The fifth edition of the 929 Challenge in Macau will include the 'Future Builders' award for the best startup in Portuguese-speaking African Countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste. Partners and projects In June, during the presentation of the competition, Marco Duarte Rizzolio, co-founder of 929 Challenge, told Lusa that the prize was created to encourage participants from less developed Portuguese-speaking countries. In 2024, the 929 Challenge did not receive any projects from Timor-Leste or São Tomé and Príncipe. The Portuguese startup Iplexmed, which develops rapid genetic diagnostic devices, won last year's edition, while the also Portuguese NS2, which provides intelligent solutions to monitor water quality for sustainable aquaculture, came third. Bruno Ferreira, co-founder of Iplexmed, will be one of the mentors at this year's 'bootcamp'. The only time that a team from PALOP and Timor-Leste reached the finalists was in the first edition, launched in 2021, in the middle of the covid-19 pandemic, then only aimed at university students. A project by the Lusófona University of Guinea-Bissau to install solar panels in the Gabu region, in the east of the country, came in second place. “In the end, those who win are often teams that already have mature products and mature services”, explained Rizzolio. This year the competition has new partners, including StartupPorto, Cabo Verde Digital and Eduardo Mondlane University, in Mozambique. The competition is co-organized by the Forum for Economic and Trade Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (Macau) and several institutions in the Chinese special administrative region, including all local universities.

item.title: “Halftone 25” | Photography exhibition opens today at FRC
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) presents today, starting at 6:30 pm, the Collective Photographic Exhibition “Halftone’ 25”, which brings together the annual works of 23 amateur and professional artists, members of Halftone — Macau Photographic Association, curated by Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro and Francisco Ricarte. The collective exhibition reveals a total of 23 works, ranging from documentary photography to artistic expression, including landscape, human, studio, conceptual, “street photography”, color or black-and-white photography. As in previous years, images were selected, some already known and others new, by authors such as André Carvalhosa, António Mil-Homens, António Sotero, António Bessa Almeida, Cássia Schutt, Catarina Cortesão Terra, Carmen Serejo, Cristiana Figueiredo, David Lopo, Elói Scarva, Francisco Ricarte, Gonçalo Lobo Pinheiro, Inela Kovacevic, Joana Freitas, João Miguel Barros, João M. Rato, João Palla Martins, Jorge Veiga Alves, José das Neves, José Sales Marques, Kuok Hou Tang, Nélson Silva and Nuno Calçada Bastos. Halftone is a non-profit cultural association created in 2021, based in Macau, which aims to promote contemporary photography in all its aspects. Founded in an inclusive and comprehensive way, it is open to all those interested in photography as an artistic or documentary expression, regardless of their experience or practice. Além de dinamizar o trabalho fotográfico dos seus associados, a Halftone tem ainda o propósito de organizar exposições, publicar uma revista, livros e monografias, organizar debates e desenvolver projectos pedagógicos e educativos. Esta exposição vai estar patente até ao dia 25 de Outubro, 2025.

item.title: Death | António Coelho dies aged 77, but leaves a legacy in Portuguese gastronomy
item.description: The founder of Restaurante António died on Sunday in Macau, due to heart problems. Behind him, he leaves a mark and an innovative concept for promoting Portuguese food in Asia A father, a friend and one of the great ambassadors of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia. Chef António Coelho died on Sunday, aged 77, due to heart problems, but leaves behind a professional career spanning almost 40 years and an influence that can be felt in several restaurants and Portuguese food chefs in Macau. Born in Portugal in 1948, António Coelho's first contact with Macau took place in 1970, when he had to complete his four-year mandatory military service. After two years, the land remained in his memory, but the future chef chose to return to Europe. In Portugal, he started working at Social Security, later moving to a clinical analysis laboratory. It was in this area that he developed his taste for gastronomy, not through work, but through various lunches and dinners in different restaurants. Increasingly interested in cooking, António decided to take a job, in 1984, in a restaurant, where he admitted to having learned to cook, according to an interview with the South China Morning Post newspaper, in 2018. The first years of António Coelho's new career were spent in Portugal, where he performed different roles as manager-administrator of the Botequim do Rei restaurant or director of the catering department at the Grande Hotel da Curia. In 1996, he had his first international experience, as director of the restaurant department at the Hotel Trópico, in Cape Verde. The experience lasts one year. Creating a legacy Returning to Macau in 1997, António worked for 10 years in different spaces, such as the restaurants Frol de la Mar, Lusitano Lisboa, and also had a brief stay in Hong Kong, in 2002, at Restaurante Inn. However, the decisive step towards his affirmation as one of the most influential chefs of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia came in 2007, with the opening of Restaurante António. And the success that followed was not the result of chance, as said by Edgar Rodrigues, a chef who came to Macau to work on the launch of the project: “The success was based on the recipes, the quality of the food, but also the very professionalism”, says Edgar Rodrigues, to HM. "He was very attentive to his customers. If there was an order for clams à bolhão pato, he would have different recipes adapted to the nationality. For example, Koreans don't like coriander, the recipe for them didn't have coriander. Chinese customers like little salt, they were served with little salt, and locals like the more traditional recipe. In a single dish there were several ways of cooking, just to satisfy different customers", he recalls. Cristiano Tavares, currently chef at the Macalhau restaurant, also came to Macau to work at the António Restaurant. He believes that the chef found a position for Portuguese food that still influences other restaurants today. “I think his success was due to his way of being, he was a politically correct person, he had a way of working that pleased both Chinese, Korean and Japanese tourists”, explained Cristiano Tavares, to HM. "We were a street restaurant with four or five cooks. He managed to do what many large restaurants still cannot do today. Nowadays there are many restaurants with Portuguese food that open in Macau, but follow the example of what he did", he considered. Quality and spectacle In addition to the food, Restaurante António customers were seduced by the “show”. This is the vision of Marcelino Marques, António's friend and musician who for several years livened up the space's nights, with traditional Portuguese music. "The quality of the food made the space popular. He took great care in choosing the food and drinks served. He went to Portugal to choose wines from various regions, such as Douro or Alentejo, all of high quality, which were bottled under the António brand. People knew they weren't going to pay little, not that it was a space with luxury prices, it wasn't, but the quantity served wasn't small", recalled Marcelino Marques. However, the musician believes that the success was also due to a concept in which the meal was also a spectacle: "People liked listening to Portuguese music, but also being with António. He was an affable, big person and appeared in that white jacket with the flags of Portugal, China and Macau and people liked his presence and asked him to take photographs", he says. "He also opened a bottle of champagne with a sword. He did a whole ceremony and people really liked it. It was a spectacle and a party to see the cork flying out of the bottle. It worked well", he recalled. Marcelino Marques recalls that the food and the show made the restaurant very famous, especially among Japanese, Korean and Hong Kong tourists. The musician reveals that Japanese tourists booked days in advance. And this factor also contributed to the fact that António offered a glass of port wine at the end of the meal, which also led to the recognition of the Port Wine Confraternity. The success of Restaurante António led the chef to sell the space to an investment fund, becoming an ambassador for the space. The break with the fund happened in 2020, when he was fired without just cause. The case ended up in court, with António winning the case. In recent years, António took on the position of executive chef at Angela’s Café and Lounge, at the Hotel Lisboeta. A father, a friend Due to his work in Macau, António was distinguished, in 2013, by the Macao SAR Government with the MSAR Tourist Merit Medal. Also in 2015, he received the merit medal for Portuguese communities from the Portuguese Government. However, for those who worked with him the most important thing was the relationship that went beyond the strictly professional field. "He had a big impact on Macau and for me he was like a second father. When I came to Macau I didn't have an easy life and he always held my hand", confessed Rodrigues. "He was always a person who was there for me. And I always saw him as a man of iron. In everything he did, there was a great will", he pointed out. This is a feeling shared by Cristiano Tavares. "António is my father in Macau. He worked until the last day, always with seriousness, honesty and integrity. He is an example for all the chefs in this area", he said. For Marcelino Marques, António's death is the loss of a friend. "António was the person who welcomed me to Macau and was capable of doing the same to everyone. He was strict and demanding, but he was an excellent person", he described. "Everyone knew him. He was an affable person and received people like no one else", he added.

item.title: Works | Merchants on Rua dos Mercadores complain about the impact
item.description:
Despite planning and advance warnings from the Government, traders on Rua dos Mercadores believe that the new works are keeping customers away, raising dust and causing a lot of noise
Shopkeepers on Rua dos Mercadores complain that they are being affected by the works for the future installation of pipes. Work began last week, but stores report that they are already feeling that customers are avoiding that area. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, a trader surnamed Chao stated that because of the inconvenience caused by the works, customers have no desire to go to stores or even frequent the area. Chao criticized the works due to the loud and frequent noise, as well as the dust raised by the excavations. The trader also criticized the signage at the location, and stated that some customers passing by were left with the idea that the streets were closed to pedestrians. In addition to the reduction in the number of customers, the complaints are about the fact that vehicles are no longer able to travel on the road. With vehicles unloading far from stores, materials need to be loaded. However, the process means that the store doors are left open, which means that construction dust penetrates the spaces and ends up affecting the entire interior. Although the Government has widened some sidewalks, Chao confessed that the widening has limited effects on the attractiveness of that street, because the sidewalks continue to be narrow. The ongoing works aim to install ducts so that, in the future, pipes can pass from other buildings, without the need to re-excavate the road. However, Chao considers that the work is not justified because it has no benefits for traders, only inconveniences. Therefore, the businessman hopes that the Government will financially support the affected businesses: “Instead of apologizing and understanding, given that we have no other choice, I prefer that they present support measures”, he stated. Evils for good The works were also criticized by a store worker named Cheong. This employee indicated that the work disturbs passers-by, making circulation on sidewalks more difficult, in addition to being carried out with incessant noise, which lasts throughout the day, and clouds of dust. However, Cheong considers that the work could be acceptable if it serves, as promised by the Government, to reduce the number of road interventions in the area. According to the Government, the execution of the works aims to open and install the ducts so that in the future it will be possible to make piping and drainage connections to four new buildings in that area, without the need to re-excavate the streets.

item.title: Macau | Portuguese folk dance registered as Intangible Cultural Heritage
item.description: Macau yesterday announced the inscription of 12 events, including Portuguese folk dance and local pastéis de nata, inspired by Portuguese pastel, on the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of the semi-autonomous Chinese region. The registration was confirmed in an order, signed by the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, dated September 26th, but which was only published today in the Macau Official Gazette. The territory's Intangible Cultural Heritage List now also includes the making of Jook-Sing pasta (a rare specialty made with duck eggs), almond cookies, traditional Chinese wedding cakes and cream puffs. Macau's custard tarts, inspired by the Portuguese pastry, were invented by a Brit living in the city, Andrew Stow (1955-2006). The list also includes the belief and customs of Tou Tei (the Chinese god of the Earth), the dragon boat festival and regatta, the dragon dance, the lion dance, the Spring Festival (which includes the Lunar New Year) and the martial art Tai Chi.

item.title: IAS | Vulnerable families with second subsidy this month
item.description: The Institute of Social Action (IAS) will grant, this month, the second grant of a support subsidy for vulnerable families, the “Community Inclusion and Harmony Program”, in order to “help alleviate the life pressure of the three types of families in vulnerable situations”, such as single-parent families, families with disabled members and families with chronically ill people. Families that are beneficiaries of this IAS support can receive this month, simultaneously, “the regular subsidy and the special subsidy through bank transfer or in the previously established manner, with the total number of families benefiting from the two subsidies being 1,283”. In total, there are 6,128 families that meet the requirements of the “Regulation of the Program for Inclusion and Harmony in the Community”, which involves an expenditure of approximately 42.92 million patacas. In relation to the beneficiary families who submitted the request to the IAS or to the collaborating associations or institutions, and whose request was granted, the special subsidy will be granted to them from this Wednesday, 15th, through bank transfer or in cash, with the total number of beneficiary families in this context being 4,845. In a single-parent family, the special subsidy will amount to 2,650 patacas, while in a family of three the support is 5,500. In a family with eight or more people, the value rises to 10,100 patacas.

item.title: China-PLP Trade | Si Ka Lon calls for improved services
item.description:
Recently re-elected deputy, Si Ka Lon questioned the Government about the “Conduct China-Portuguese Speaking Countries” service platform, asking for the service to improve, namely with the creation of a certification system, in order to take more local brands abroad
Deputy Si Ka Lon, recently elected indirectly by the industrial, commercial and financial sectors, sent a new question to the Executive in which he defends an improvement in services provided by the “China-Portuguese Speaking Countries Trade Conduct” platform, which aims to “provide a series of connection and support services to companies, institutions and individuals interested in exploring and developing the markets of China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, such as “consultancy and business forwarding”, among other services. In the interpellation, Si Ka Lon questions the effectiveness of the services provided to date and asks for new support structures to be created. “Currently the ‘China-PLP Trade Conduct’ services focus on administrative issues and the provision of information, but the Government can study the launch of more advanced and attractive complementary measures, such as the establishment of an official certification regime”, he suggested. Si Ka Lon also added the idea of ​​creating a “brand incubation and advertising support” service, so that “the services are updated in order to give this platform a greater degree of training, to increase the attractiveness and competitiveness of local brands when they enter the foreign market”. The deputy linked to the Fujian community wants to know what strategies the Government has in place to attract high-value brands to the Macau market and how the local market can be taken advantage of to explore foreign markets. Incubators needed Si Ka Lon highlighted that, taking into account the situation of “dual circulation” of goods and services with the country and China's strategy of opening up to the outside world, it can lead to the efficient performance of Macau's specific advantages in supporting brands of excellence in Mainland China, so that they can have a greater presence in international markets. The deputy considers this to be an essential means for Macau to diversify its economy and explore new points of growth. As for the incubation of local brands, the deputy wants to know more details. Si Ka Lon recalled that the Government said that the China-Portuguese-Speaking Countries Limited Partnership Cooperation and Development Fund would be carrying out a study and visiting local companies with a view to exploring their degree of excellence, especially companies that start business with Portuguese-speaking countries. "What are the plans and ideas? How will a closer connection be established with associations and industrial entities so that coordinated development can be implemented between brands from Macau and mainland China to enter the foreign market?", he asked.

item.title: FIMM | Thomas Hampson plays Mahler this week on CCM
item.description: This Thursday, the 16th, the world-renowned baritone Thomas Hampson will perform in Macau, who will perform songs by Gustav Mahler for another concert as part of the 37th edition of the Macau International Music Festival. “Thomas Hampton Sings Mahler” also features German pianist Wolfgang Rieger It is another highlight of the 37th edition of the Macau International Music Festival (FIMM): this Thursday, October 16th, Thomas Hampson, protagonist of the concert “Thomas Hampton Sings Mahler”, takes to the stage in the large auditorium of the Macau Cultural Center (CCM). Accompanying him, from 8pm, will be the German pianist Wolfgang Rieger. This is a show dedicated to the “lieder” [set of compositions] by Gustav Mahler, conductor and composer born in 1860, in Bohemia, and considered one of the great names of the romantic period of classical music. The “lieder” include the song cycle “Des Knaben Wunderhorn (The Young Man’s Magic Horn)”, composed and revised between 1892 and 1901; and also the cycle of old songs “Lieder und Gesänge aus der Jugendzeit”, composed between 1880 and 1889, “illuminating the intricate poetry and complex psychological landscapes that define Mahler's art”. Furthermore, the concert program “offers a thematic journey through Mahler’s ‘Wunderhorn’ and ‘Lieder und Gesänge’ settings”, compositions “grouped into three chapters – ‘Fables and Parables’, ‘Humoresques and Ballads’ and ‘Ballads and Allegories'”, and which “trace a progression from pastoral charm and satire to existential depth and longing metaphysical.” In this way, “the public will also have the opportunity to experience a mixture of life's wisdom and esteemed musicality through the sound of his voice at the age of 70”, describes a note from the Cultural Institute (IC). Study and awards The baritone's career is full of distinctions. The IC describes that “Thomas Hampson dedicated decades to the performance, communication and academic study of Mahler's art, earning a reputation as a 'singer-scholar'”. Furthermore, “he obtained multiple honorary doctorates and received numerous international awards, including the Grammy Award, the Edison Award, or the ‘Grand Prix du Disque'”. Thomas Hampson has also received “numerous international honors for his unique artistry and cultural leadership, fully reflecting his illustrious status in classical music circles”, having a repertoire “composed of more than 80 roles, and with a discography including more than 170 albums”. Thomas Hampton is also honorary professor of Philosophy at the University of Heidelberg and honorary member of the Royal Academy of Music in London. He holds the prestigious title of “Kammersänger of the Wiener Staatsoper” and was named “Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters” by the French Republic. He is also co-founder and artistic director of the Lied Academy Heidelberg and, in 2003, founded the Hampsong Foundation, through which he uses the art of song to promote intercultural dialogue and understanding. Happy partnership Another of the musicians who takes the CCM stage, Wolfram Rieger, is a distinguished German pianist, recognized for his interpretation of “Lied”. He perfected his art in classes with Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Hans Hotter and Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau. After completing his studies, Rieger began teaching at the Munich Higher School of Music, where he founded his own Lieder class for singers and pianists in 1991. He has been Professor of “Lied” at the Hanns Eisler School of Music in Berlin since 1998, and gives masterclasses all over the world. Much sought after as a recital partner and chamber musician, Rieger performs in renowned venues such as Wigmore Hall, Carnegie Hall, the Konzerthaus in Vienna and at festivals such as the Schubertiade in Feldkirch and Salzburg. His collaborators include Thomas Hampson, Thomas Quasthoff, Brigitte Fassbaender and Matthias Goerne. His renowned recordings earned him distinctions such as the Hugo Wolf Medal and the Medal of the Franz Schubert Association of Barcelona. Ticket prices for this recital vary between 150 and 400 patacas.

item.title: Xiaomi | Shares fall 6% after accident with a brand car
item.description: Shares of Chinese technology company Xiaomi fell 5.71 percent yesterday, after an accident involving one of its electric vehicles caught fire and caused the death of the driver. According to the news portal The Paper, the driver of the SU7 model lost control of the vehicle during the early hours of yesterday and crashed into an avenue in the city of Chengdu, in central China, immediately catching fire. Witnesses cited by the same media reported that several passers-by tried to put out the fire and open the doors, even breaking the windows with objects, but the driver was trapped inside. According to reports, the car was traveling at a speed of more than 100 kilometers per hour when it tried to avoid another car that slowed down to turn right. Chengdu firefighters continue to investigate the causes of the accident. Yesterday's fall took Xiaomi's shares to their lowest level since April, when a similar accident – ​​also involving an electric vehicle from the brand that caught fire on a highway in eastern China and caused three deaths – caused a sharp decline in the company's market value. Traditionally associated with the production of mobile phones and smart devices, Xiaomi has invested in diversifying its business by entering the competitive electric vehicle sector, dominated in China by brands such as BYD and Tesla.

item.title: Customs | 21 people arrested for circulating books containing pornography
item.description: The Gongbei Customs Service says it has detained 21 people in two years for circulating 25,299 copies of books considered “obscene”, that is, with pornographic content. According to a statement from the authorities, three rounds of operations were carried out during this period of time to combat this type of crime, with the first action of its kind taking place on March 13, 2023. At that time, a cross-border driver was stopped trying to enter Macau through the Hengqin Border Post with 86 books in the car. Anti-smuggling police later managed to discover this man's employer. It was realized that the cross-border driver had already managed to transport 894 “obscene” books to Mainland China. Later, another group was discovered carrying out this type of smuggling, with networks in Zhuhai and Foshan, and which was linked to this employer. The group was dismantled by the authorities in June 2023. In turn, in August last year another man was discovered who maintained close contacts with this group and was also arrested. At that time, another group that circulated “obscene” books by sea was also dismantled. Smuggling | 18 cases in the last two weeks The Customs Service (SA) says it has discovered, in the last two weeks, 18 cases of smuggling at the Border Posts of Portas do Cerco and the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge, between the 26th of September and the 9th of October. According to a SA statement, 991 old cell phones, 9.16 kilograms of undeclared food, nine bottles of Chinese liquor, 6006 grams of cigars and 68 cosmetic products were discovered by intercepted smugglers. The SA also reported that the smugglers are residents of Macau, Hong Kong and Mainland China, and were charged under the Foreign Trade Law.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description: The philosophical questions that will arise throughout this text are based on concrete data, they are not inventions and depend on newspaper reports, but they are certainly not fake news, they just report what has been happening in the second decade of the 21st century in the People's Republic of China. China is the market leader in robotic technology, including humanoid robotics. Robotics malls are growing in Beijing, one with 4 floors, opened on August 7, 2025, another with 6 floors in Shenzhen. In this large shopping mall, there are robots for all tastes and uses in assisting medicine, industry and everyday activities. They can be bionic, with shapes and movements inspired by biology, or humanoid, reaching levels of sophistication like those seen in a chess player named Wukong. We also find them linked to sport, some play boxing, others football, others practice running, there are artists, for example, painters, musicians and dancers, there are medical assistants, masseurs, nursing technicians and laboratory assistants, and/or dedicated to traditional Chinese medicine, there are them committed to daily tasks, making excellent waiters and cooks, who attentively flip pancakes and prepare barbecues, but also counter staff, there are, in addition, humanoid transporters and drones. And if there are good ones, that is, used to help and build, obviously there could be bad ones, to hinder and destroy. But this is a conversation for later. At the World Robotics Conference in August 2025, held in Beijing, a sales balance was carried out for the year 2024 regarding industrial robots, which exceeded 300 thousand units, keeping China in top place in sales of this type of robots for the twelfth consecutive year. In a report made by the President of the Chinese Robotics Institute, Xu Xiaolan (徐晓兰), the country is the largest producer of robotics in the world, with sales of industrial robots having increased from 33,000 in 2015 to 556,000 units in 2024. The production of service robots (domestic services, storage and logistics, commercial services, support for the elderly, the disabled and rehabilitation medical) for more than 10 million units. In statistical terms, and according to data from the International Data Corporation (IDC) for 2024, Chinese manufacturers occupy 84.7% of the global market for commercial service robots. China leads the world robotics market, through its active creative industry, as it had already done in relation, for example, to toys. The country is responsible for around 80% to 90% of toys sold globally, whether old wooden toys, plush toys, inflatable toys, or electronic toys, with Guangdong, Jiangsu and Shandong being the main bases for purchasing toys, with the centers of Fujian, Zhejiang and Shanghai also being strong in this area. Centers that we also find linked to robotics, at least in the case of Shanghai and Shenzhen. Can a relationship be established between toys and robotics in the case of China? Toys are a strong focus of generation Z, short for zoomers, (those from the second half of the 90s until 2010), who fear a bleak future and invest a lot in emotional spending. This generation of the World Wide Web follows the growth of technological devices, being considered digital native. As I believe, the path for the emergence of robots in China was laid out long before Generation Z appeared on the face of the earth. The Chinese have always loved toys, see their love for stuffed animals, lanterns, old wooden toys and, more recently, all types of electronic toys. Now, robots, although they are much more than entertainment, have the appearance of toys, with the added advantage of being able to receive a strong emotional investment, combined with enormous practical utility. These “cans”, made from aluminum, steel and titanium, and plastics, such as polypropylene, ABS and polycarbonate, rubbers and elastomers, in addition to numerous electronic components, such as microprocessors, sensors, motors and wiring, are great companions of humans, faithful friends and obedience only limited to their manufacture. They therefore appear to fulfill several functions and their emergence was only possible due to a close alliance between science and technology, that is, due to the development of technology, which was thematized by great contemporary writers and philosophers in the West, and think of Aldous Huxley (1894-1963) and his futuristic dystopia, entitled Brave New World. 1932), in which a society dominated by genetic engineering is psychologically conditioned, including by drugs (soma), in order to guarantee social well-being and suppress freedom and critical thinking. Consider, also, works such as Oswald Spengler's (1880-1936), Man and Technique from 1931, which explores the relationship between human beings and technology, ultimately leading to self-destruction through the dissolution of Western culture. But if Western culture can feel, to paraphrase Spengler, “nauseated by machines”, there are others like the philosopher Martin Heidegger (1889-1976), who in The Question of Technique (1954) sees technique as the meaning of a new era for human beings. However, to do so it is necessary to know how to question the technique and not just accept it in an instrumental way at the service of anthropological purposes, when humanism for the philosopher of The Letter to Humanism (1946) has disastrous consequences, because it distances the true man from his essence and Being, which is thus hidden and not revealed. None of these paths of Western thought have been followed by the Chinese of our times, strongly committed to the utilitarian use of technology. The instrumentalization of it at the service of humanity, or rather, of China, does not raise existential doubts in them, as is attested by the large robotics shopping malls currently available in Beijing or Shenzhen to a public eager for technological innovations. Chinese robots serve all types of functions; industrial, commercial, scientific, recreational, domestic and emotional assistance. The relative lack of freedom, or the limitation of degrees of freedom (Degrees of Freedom, DOF) also does not seem worrying to them, at least to the point of raising philosophical questions about a dystopian future, viable through the genetic crossing of artificial intelligence with animals, including so-called rational humans. They only seek to improve the degrees of freedom of robots defined as the number of independent movements of their joints and components, carried out in both the rotational and translational directions, these degrees being in the Humanoid Robotic Technology article, published in May 2025, variable according to the technical improvement of each machine: the greatest degree of freedom is presented by the Era-Star 1 Robot. Therefore, do not expect great and unusual innovations regarding the degree of freedom of robots, they will be, until you see, limited and submissive to their creators. From a good creator a positive robot will emerge, from a bad creator, a negative one. A friend with whom I discussed the topic was very surprised by the fact that one of the most populous countries in the world is at the forefront of robotic development, because for him it would be more important to provide employment to a huge population than to seek to replace them in almost all tasks, from scientific to the most routine, such as the transport and delivery of goods. To understand why this total adherence to intelligent machinery, or as intelligent as its limited freedom allows, it is necessary to go back to the history of China. I propose a journey to the times of the emergence and development of the use of gunpowder. The appearance of gunpowder is associated with Alchemy and Taoist masters, who carried out the first scientific experiments in search of the elixir of longevity, already in the Warring States Period (战国 Zhàn Guó, 475-221 BC), being one of the four great inventions of Ancient China (四大发明Sì dà fāmíng). The first type of gunpowder to emerge was black gunpowder (黑火药Hēi huǒyào), the experiments of the alchemists were very well received and encouraged by the dominant power, then the experiments continued during the Eastern Han dynasty (东汉Dōng Hàn, 25-220), with the treatise by Wei Boyang (魏伯阳), entitled Zhouyi Cantongqi, being famous. (《周易参同契》), and translated as The Concordance of the Three, or that of the Jin dynasty (晋代Jìn dài, 266-420) by the great alchemist Ge Hong (葛洪), whose title is Baopuzi, in Portuguese, The Master Who Embraces Simplicity (《抱朴子·仙药篇》), especially its chapter dedicated to the manufacture of the pill of immortality. Perhaps when using combustion methods to create the pill, the alchemists discovered gunpowder by chance by mixing sulfur, saltpeter and charcoal. It is certain that the explosion occurred and the dangerous, flammable and detonating element was discovered, but it is no less certain that the masters did not follow this route, which they considered unproductive for the desired objective. Then only much later during the Song dynasty (宋代Sòng dài， 960-1279) is it known that some artisans established fireworks workshops in Kaifeng to produce rockets and fireworks indispensable for all great moments of celebration in China. The use of gunpowder then followed two very different paths, one pyrotechnic for recreational purposes of the imperial power and associated stately homes, the other for military use. Why is the story of the discovery of gunpowder brought here? Because this could perhaps contain the three dimensions that we can find in the creation and interest in robots in China. Its creation reveals an enormous scientific interest associated: on the one hand, with philosophical practices aimed at developing life to its limits and perhaps even their absence, which would be achieved by immortality; on the other, it expresses an immense recreational desire with deep emotional investment, and, on the other, a practical utility, which puts robotics at the forefront, both in scientific, military and civil terms. The new Chinese philosophy, as the oldest genuinely autochthonous one, appears in close connection with science and techniques with mysterious connections to the world of magic for the Taoist masters of yesterday, who are followed by the great doctors, including those of traditional Chinese medicine, who today find precious laboratory assistants carrying out work of great precision and minimal errors, since robots do not They get tired, they don't even bother, they do what is asked of them without any salary demands. Furthermore, in military terms this arsenal of machinery is an excellent alternative, as it saves lives, as it is complex and autonomous enough to do so. Obviously, of the many ethical issues associated with this exponential development of the new world of robotics and artificial intelligence, one seems essential, above all and, for now, in terms of biotechnical experimentation and related scientific research, which will be discussed below. First the example, taken from the development of dynamic electrodes for brain-computer interface, as is happening at the Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. In brain-computer interface systems, electrodes from electronic devices must be connected to the brain to acquire electroencephalographic signals. These electrodes are made of flexible fiber, similar to a worm, with a magnetic sensor incorporated in the head of the “worm”, to be manipulated according to the orientation of external magnetic fields. These flexible fiber electrodes were introduced into the brains of rabbits and also rats, with the aim of subsequently serving human clinical needs, such as intelligent control of prostheses, localization of epileptic lesions and treatment of chronic neurological disorders. From an ethical point of view, the question cannot help but be asked: why are human lives more important than all others on our planet? Human beings remain the kings of creation, even within the scope of philosophies such as the Chinese, whose non-humanist tradition, as referred to in Heidegger's Letter to Humanism, is well known. Are we humans really that valuable? Science must continue its path, which in China will always be followed from a pragmatic and utilitarian perspective for the benefit of the Chinese and the Chinese nation. But don't think that robotics is there just to serve Chinese society without exchanging favors, as we cannot forget the enormous emotional investment that the population that descends from Dragons makes in these new beings, some more bionic than others, who acquire the status of companions and friends and, in this capacity, have all the pampering that was previously due to the humans and animals they chose to cherish. The new Chinese philosophy is utilitarian, practical and has new entities in its world of knowledge, such as humanoids, bionic robots and robotics toys. They are highly esteemed and paving the way for a new era, that of cyborgs or better said, the mixed humanity of tomorrow, which will have the greatest chance of living long and, who knows, immortalizing itself. item.title: Chemistry | Nobel Prize for the development of metal-organic structures
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Susumu Kitagawa, from Kyoto University, Richard Robson, from the University of Melbourne, and Omar M. Yaghi, from the University of California, “for the development of metal-organic structures”, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences announced yesterday. Susumu Kitagawa, Richard Robson and Omar Yaghi have developed a new form of molecular architecture – metal-organic frameworks – that can be used to collect water from desert air, capture carbon dioxide, store toxic gases or catalyze chemical reactions. The three laureates created molecular constructs with large spaces through which gases and other chemicals could flow. The president of the Nobel Committee for Chemistry, Heiner Linque, highlighted precisely the fact that these “metal-organic structures have enormous potential, bringing previously unforeseen opportunities for personalized materials with new functions”. The research that led to the discovery of this new form of molecular architecture began nearly four decades ago, in 1989, when Richard Robson tested the use of the inherent properties of atoms by combining positively charged copper ions with a four-armed molecule. When combined, they bonded "to form a spacious, well-ordered crystal. It was like a diamond filled with countless cavities," the academy explains. Robson immediately realized the potential of his molecular construction, but it was still unstable and crumbled easily. It was chemists Susumu Kitagawa and Omar Yaghi who managed to provide a solid foundation for this construction method. Notable applications Following the discoveries of the three laureates, chemists built tens of thousands of different MOFs. Some of them could contribute to solving some of humanity's biggest challenges, with applications including breaking down traces of pharmaceuticals in the environment, capturing carbon dioxide or collecting water from desert air. The discovery also allows the separation of perfluoroalkylated and polyfluoroalkylated substances (PFAS) from water. PFAS are a group of synthetic chemical compounds known as “forever chemicals” due to their extreme persistence in the environment and in the human body. PFAS are used in a wide range of industrial and household products, such as stain- and water-resistant textiles, food packaging, non-stick cookware and firefighting foams. Its accumulation in the environment and potential health risks, including liver damage and other problems, have led to concerns and a search for safer alternatives.

item.title: Study | Trump was the main disseminator of disinformation in the USA in 2024
item.description: North American President Donald Trump was the main disseminator of disinformation in the United States of America (USA) in 2024, concluded a study by the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ). “US President Donald Trump was the dominant source and distributor of disinformation” in 2024, say the authors of the study “Disarming Disinformation: United States”. The study highlights that Trump has drawn on the functions of domestic political forces, rather than foreign state actors, as the main source of disinformation narratives in US political discourse. Furthermore, the existence of WhatsApp groups and other closed digital spaces often act as “information cocoons” that encourage rumors and other forms of misinformation. In this way, "the viral spread of misinformation and the strategic attack on journalists have emerged as interconnected threats to democracy. In an era of increasing authoritarianism and democratic backsliding, falsehoods are often used as a weapon by state actors to influence public opinion, undermine journalism and intimidate journalists." The study authors state that these factors are increasingly the North American reality, with Donald Trump “promulgating manifestly false narratives” in recent years. “The American media faces a profound information crisis, at a time of repression of freedom of expression”, the study reads. In this sense, trust in the mainstream press continues to decline in a climate of increasing attacks on the media by the Trump Government. The study published by the International Center for Journalists (ICFJ) was based on the analysis of 10,000 news and media publications during 2024, as well as a survey of 1,020 Americans.

item.title: Scientists ‘reduce’ the age of the Egyptian temple of Karnak, in Egypt
item.description: Researchers have carried out the most comprehensive geoarchaeological study of the Karnak temple, near Luxor, and revealed suggestive links to ancient Egyptian mythology and new data about the interaction between the complex's riverine landscape and the people who occupied the site during its almost 3,000 years of use. The results of the investigation were published on Monday in Antiquity magazine, reported the Efe news agency. Researchers from the University of Southampton, in the United Kingdom, and Uppsala University, in Sweden, participated in the study. Up to 61 sediment samples from the interior and surroundings of the temple and thousands of ceramic fragments found in the Karnak complex, located 500 meters east of the current Nile River, near Luxor, in the ancient Egyptian religious capital of Thebes, were analyzed. The researchers mapped how the landscape around the site changed throughout its history and found that, before 2520 BC, the site could not have been suitable for permanent occupation due to periodic flooding caused by the Nile's strong currents. Therefore, they placed the earliest occupation at Karnak during the Old Kingdom (between 2591 and 2152 BC). Pottery fragments found at the site corroborate this discovery, with the oldest dating between 2305 and 1980 BC. Therefore, the conclusions of this international team of researchers provide new evidence about the age of Karnak, which has been hotly debated in archaeological circles for decades. The origin of everything The ground on which the temple was founded was formed when river channels advanced west and east, creating an island of high ground in what is now the east-southeast region of the site. This emerging island laid the foundation for the occupation and initial construction of Karnak. Over the following centuries and millennia, the river channels on both sides of the site diverged further, creating more space for the development of the temple complex, as researchers have now confirmed. This new understanding of the temple's landscape bears striking similarities to an ancient Egyptian creation myth, leading the team to believe that the decision to locate the temple there may have been related to the religious views of its inhabitants. Ancient Egyptian texts from the Old Kingdom indicate that the 'Creator God' manifested himself as high ground emerging from the lake, and researchers have found that the island where Karnak was founded is the only known area of ​​high ground surrounded by water in the region. Thus, archaeologists have suggested that the Theban elites chose the location of Karnak to be the abode of a new form of 'Creator God', alluding to Amun-Ra, the supreme god of ancient Egypt, since the location fit perfectly into the mythological setting of the highlands that emerged from the surrounding waters as the origin of the formation of the Universe.

item.title: Death | António Coelho dies aged 77, but leaves a legacy in Portuguese gastronomy
item.description: The founder of Restaurante António died on Sunday in Macau, due to heart problems. Behind him, he leaves a mark and an innovative concept for promoting Portuguese food in Asia A father, a friend and one of the great ambassadors of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia. Chef António Coelho died on Sunday, aged 77, due to heart problems, but leaves behind a professional career spanning almost 40 years and an influence that can be felt in several restaurants and Portuguese food chefs in Macau. Born in Portugal in 1948, António Coelho's first contact with Macau took place in 1970, when he had to complete his four-year mandatory military service. After two years, the land remained in his memory, but the future chef chose to return to Europe. In Portugal, he started working at Social Security, later moving to a clinical analysis laboratory. It was in this area that he developed his taste for gastronomy, not through work, but through various lunches and dinners in different restaurants. Increasingly interested in cooking, António decided to take a job, in 1984, in a restaurant, where he admitted to having learned to cook, according to an interview with the South China Morning Post newspaper, in 2018. The first years of António Coelho's new career were spent in Portugal, where he performed different roles as manager-administrator of the Botequim do Rei restaurant or director of the catering department at the Grande Hotel da Curia. In 1996, he had his first international experience, as director of the restaurant department at the Hotel Trópico, in Cape Verde. The experience lasts one year. Creating a legacy Returning to Macau in 1997, António worked for 10 years in different spaces, such as the restaurants Frol de la Mar, Lusitano Lisboa, and also had a brief stay in Hong Kong, in 2002, at Restaurante Inn. However, the decisive step towards his affirmation as one of the most influential chefs of Portuguese gastronomy in Asia came in 2007, with the opening of Restaurante António. And the success that followed was not the result of chance, as said by Edgar Rodrigues, a chef who came to Macau to work on the launch of the project: “The success was based on the recipes, the quality of the food, but also the very professionalism”, says Edgar Rodrigues, to HM. "He was very attentive to his customers. If there was an order for clams à bolhão pato, he would have different recipes adapted to the nationality. For example, Koreans don't like coriander, the recipe for them didn't have coriander. Chinese customers like little salt, they were served with little salt, and locals like the more traditional recipe. In a single dish there were several ways of cooking, just to satisfy different customers", he recalls. Cristiano Tavares, currently chef at the Macalhau restaurant, also came to Macau to work at the António Restaurant. He believes that the chef found a position for Portuguese food that still influences other restaurants today. “I think his success was due to his way of being, he was a politically correct person, he had a way of working that pleased both Chinese, Korean and Japanese tourists”, explained Cristiano Tavares, to HM. "We were a street restaurant with four or five cooks. He managed to do what many large restaurants still cannot do today. Nowadays there are many restaurants with Portuguese food that open in Macau, but follow the example of what he did", he considered. Quality and spectacle In addition to the food, Restaurante António customers were seduced by the “show”. This is the vision of Marcelino Marques, António's friend and musician who for several years livened up the space's nights, with traditional Portuguese music. "The quality of the food made the space popular. He took great care in choosing the food and drinks served. He went to Portugal to choose wines from various regions, such as Douro or Alentejo, all of high quality, which were bottled under the António brand. People knew they weren't going to pay little, not that it was a space with luxury prices, it wasn't, but the quantity served wasn't small", recalled Marcelino Marques. However, the musician believes that the success was also due to a concept in which the meal was also a spectacle: "People liked listening to Portuguese music, but also being with António. He was an affable, big person and appeared in that white jacket with the flags of Portugal, China and Macau and people liked his presence and asked him to take photographs", he says. "He also opened a bottle of champagne with a sword. He did a whole ceremony and people really liked it. It was a spectacle and a party to see the cork flying out of the bottle. It worked well", he recalled. Marcelino Marques recalls that the food and the show made the restaurant very famous, especially among Japanese, Korean and Hong Kong tourists. The musician reveals that Japanese tourists booked days in advance. And this factor also contributed to the fact that António offered a glass of port wine at the end of the meal, which also led to the recognition of the Port Wine Confraternity. The success of Restaurante António led the chef to sell the space to an investment fund, becoming an ambassador for the space. The break with the fund happened in 2020, when he was fired without just cause. The case ended up in court, with António winning the case. In recent years, António took on the position of executive chef at Angela’s Café and Lounge, at the Hotel Lisboeta. A father, a friend Due to his work in Macau, António was distinguished, in 2013, by the Macao SAR Government with the MSAR Tourist Merit Medal. Also in 2015, he received the merit medal for Portuguese communities from the Portuguese Government. However, for those who worked with him the most important thing was the relationship that went beyond the strictly professional field. "He had a big impact on Macau and for me he was like a second father. When I came to Macau I didn't have an easy life and he always held my hand", confessed Rodrigues. "He was always a person who was there for me. And I always saw him as a man of iron. In everything he did, there was a great will", he pointed out. This is a feeling shared by Cristiano Tavares. "António is my father in Macau. He worked until the last day, always with seriousness, honesty and integrity. He is an example for all the chefs in this area", he said. For Marcelino Marques, António's death is the loss of a friend. "António was the person who welcomed me to Macau and was capable of doing the same to everyone. He was strict and demanding, but he was an excellent person", he described. "Everyone knew him. He was an affable person and received people like no one else", he added.

item.title: Physics | Nobel Prize for Macroscopic Quantum Mechanical Tunneling
item.description: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret and John M. Martinis “for the discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunneling and the quantization of energy in an electrical circuit”, announced yesterday the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. "An important question in physics is the maximum size of a system capable of demonstrating the effects of quantum mechanics. This year's Nobel Prize laureates carried out experiments with an electrical circuit in which they demonstrated both quantum tunneling and quantized energy levels in a system large enough to be held in the hand", explains the Swedish Academy of Sciences in a statement published on its website. The British John Clarke carried out his research at the University of California, Berkeley, USA; the American John Martinis at the University of California, Santa Barbara; and the Frenchman Michel Devoret at Yale University and also in California, Santa Barbara. According to academia, quantum mechanics allows a particle to directly cross a barrier, through a process called tunneling. When a large number of particles are involved, quantum effects usually become negligible. The experiments of the now distinguished scientists demonstrated that quantum properties can be made concrete on a macroscopic scale. "It is wonderful to be able to celebrate the way in which quantum mechanics, more than a century old, continues to offer new surprises. It is also extremely useful, as it is the basis of all digital technology", said the president of the Nobel Committee for Physics, Olle Eriksson, quoted in the statement. The Swedish academy says that transistors in computer microchips are an example of consolidated quantum technology. The scientists today awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics share a prize of 11 million Swedish kronor (almost one million euros).

item.title: Linguistics | Published study based on a trip to Macau in the 19th century
item.description:
Academic Anabela Leal de Barros has just published a linguistic study that focuses on the trip of Father Miranda e Oliveira, linked to the Congregation of the Mission, to Macau in 1825. With touches of history, details are revealed about the Portuguese of the time and of Macau. The book will be presented at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center next Wednesday
“Journey from Lisbon to Macau – 1825” is the title of the most recent work published by Grão-Falar, written by University of Minho academic Anabela Leal de Barros. The book makes a critical and interpretative analysis of the Portuguese of the time left in the manuscript of parish priest José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira, priest of the Congregation of the Mission. This documentation is kept by the Braga District Archive. However, the work does not just explore the Portuguese of the time, revealing other historical details of Macau, Asia and a sea voyage. As Anabela Leal de Barros told HM, the work is “as faithful as possible to the spelling of the manuscript”, until now practically unknown. In this travel diary, Father Miranda e Oliveira “reveals enormous curiosity about all the news and shares with us their names in the languages ​​of the world in which they were baptized, starting with ours”. This is how he explains situations such as “seasickness, a reality that was still relatively unknown and highly invasive on boats” in those times. The priest named or defined “the mangalhões, the porpoises, the caravels, the black-eyed peas, the flies, the albacores — all sorts of birds and fish that were admired, fished or tasted throughout the trip”, or even the “meteorological phenomena with local names – cacimba, samatra, typhoon”. There are also details about “cultural habits such as the masca, buio in Indonesian; the Philippine seges, the berloches, and the ruling class of the camisolas, as well as the sômas, Chinese vessels”. The vessel left Lisbon in April 1825 and spent time in the Philippines, arriving in Macau on October 23rd. The arrival “to the island of Caó” and the following day “to Colégio de S. José” is described, to “a city with ‘a magnificent port of commerce’, located ‘on a very pleasant peninsula’, with ‘good waters’ and ‘famous European-style buildings'”. Linguistic varieties In the work published by Grão-Falar there are, for example, “rich stories such as that of Orvalhadas de S. João, Caldeirão de Frei Junípero or the habit of seafarers shouting ‘Refresca S. Lourenço!’ so that the wind blows, this being the meaning here of ‘refresh’”. There are also “allusions to the linguistic variety itself”, as “at various times there is reference to communication with foreigners carried out in Latin, in Indonesian-Dutch and Filipino-Spanish territory; the private teaching of English in the Philippines by members of the Congregation of the Mission; the little knowledge and use of Spanish, even in Manila, and the variation of Tagalog itself, a language in which the priest is concerned about recording the Hail Mary.” Before arriving at this travel report, Anabela Leal de Barros was already in the intricacies of investigating this type of manuscripts, coming across the story of another priest, “the greatest Portuguese sinologist, Joaquim Afonso Gonçalves, who had traveled from the same house as Rilhafoles of the Congregation of the Mission to Macau in 1812”. According to the author, this parish priest “dedicated the last twenty-nine years of his life to the mission of evangelization in China, and in particular to the research and teaching of Chinese at the Colégio de S. José in Macau”. In his entire life, “this Trás-os-Montes native wrote more than five thousand pages of grammars and dictionaries in Portuguese, Latin and Chinese, expressly dedicated to his students at the College, seven printed in his typography and at least two manuscripts”. Then, in 2017, António Lázaro, from the History Department of the University of Minho, and director of the Confúcio Institute, made available to Anabela Leal de Barros “a list of references to manuscripts from the Braga District Archive about Macau and China”. A “journey” began, which culminated in the publication of this study. “This book is the first result of a project of mine to edit and study unpublished travel literature manuscripts whose main objective is exactly this: to contribute to the appreciation and consolidation of the micro-history of the Discoveries and the memory of history, between the 15th and 19th centuries”. Accompanied on the trip José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira took around seven months to arrive in Macau, leaving Lisbon on April 1, 1825, and arriving in Oriente on October 24 of the same year. He left on the ship Vasco da Gama with three other priests from the congregation: João da França de Castro e Moura, Jerónimo José da Mata and José́ Ferreira da Silva. According to Anabela Leal de Barros, “the manuscript does not appear to have been cleaned by the author himself, given the type of spelling variations and typos and amendments it presents”, having probably been “translated, to safeguard copies, by a Macanese member of the College, since Macau Portuguese, in the 19th century, had characteristics compatible with certain traits, strange in a priest arrived from Portugal, even how young.” This travel diary “ends on the very day of arrival in Macau, with a very brief presentation of the city and the school, making clear the Catholic perspective of the time in relation to the Chinese cult of ancestors and without failing to draw attention to the mere five thousand Christians among the 40 to 50 thousand inhabitants of the city”. Political hostilities José Joaquim de Miranda e Oliveira describes how the bishop of Macau did not receive the delegation, which is “enough to lead us to the hostile context in which the Lazarists, defenders of liberalism, found themselves, which had led Joaquim Afonso Gonçalves, a few years earlier, to take refuge in the Philippines, with the school missing two of its teachers”. Furthermore, “along the journey the priest does not fail to narrate all the moments in which he carries out his daily mission, with the administration of the sacraments, the prayer of responsos and the celebration of masses, but above all he notes the notable lack of priests who reveal the Christianized peoples, particularly in Batavia, now Jakarta, where the community of Portuguese origin, of more than a thousand people, had only an old priest.” These reports also reveal the concern to “remember the first French martyrs of the Congregation in the attempt to evangelize Madagascar and to report the presence of friars and priests from the different congregations, from Cape Verde to the Philippines, where they are recognized as more important for the solidity of Spanish rule than its army”. According to Anabela Leal de Barros, the report also alluded, in Java, “to the Lutherans and Mohammedans, as well as to the religions of China and, in Manila, to the persecution of Christians (referring to the ‘dinner’, that is, lunch with a Chinese Christian, ‘and as such persecuted’)”. Miranda and Oliveira had “a very diplomatic and convivial conduct, ensuring the establishment and maintenance of cordial relations between the various orders and also with the governors and foreign powers present, from the Dutch to the Spanish, who visited everywhere”. An ongoing project In those years, it was a dangerous adventure to travel by boat, facing “anthropogenic peoples, piracy, diseases on ships and epidemics”, a “perfectly cinematic vision” already described in Os Lusíadas, by Luís de Camões. Those who embarked on these trips also found themselves alone, “individually and on a small ship little more than a walnut shell, facing an endless sea, for months, at times when it was common for several passengers not to reach their destination, or for not even one ship from a full squadron to return”. In Miranda and Oliveira's report, “there is no great news” compared to previous reports, but “we are aware of the main difficulties of sea voyages to Asia in the 19th century: the rocks that existed even before the Torre de Belém, which caused many shipwrecks; and seasickness, which even deserves a definition for the many readers who had never set foot on a boat, and to which the captain's face advising the sick ladies going up to the awning and working, as it was the best medicine”. There is also “the episode of the man falling overboard from the plow that accompanied them on part of the trip, which they were unable to save — a death to which everyone was so exposed, as the narrator refers”. Another potential misfortune in trips of this type also stands out, “the encounter with ships that, not immediately raising any flag, or raising it without giving true confidence, immediately led to the decision to light the hills and open fire, which well reflects the dimension of piracy and the fears it imposed”. Essentially, “the main character of sea voyages was the wind”, which led the still “young priest” to “evoke the Camonian verses of the storm twice”. After arriving in Macau, Miranda e Oliveira left for his post in Nanking, “on a journey comparatively longer than the first, received by the Christians with difficulty and secretly”. “In the face of persecution” he ended up succumbing “to the dangers and illnesses of the mainland, at the age of 31, far from all his confreres, on November 1, 1828, just two years after having described the difficult farewell to his spiritual family, in Lisbon”. “His traveling companions had more longevity, one of whom would become Bishop of Macau and the other of Beijing and Porto”, highlights Anabela Leal de Barros.

item.title: Ragasa | Sam Hou Fai calls for prevention so that Macau is not left to its own devices
item.description:
The Government met yesterday to discuss civil protection operations due to super typhoon Ragasa. Sam Hou Fai called for prevention and Tai Kin Ip indicated that the casinos will close this afternoon, when signal 8 is issued. CNN said yesterday that, so far, Ragasa is the strongest storm this year worldwide
After making landfall yesterday on the island of Calyan in the Philippines, super typhoon Ragasa advanced through the South China Sea, following a trajectory that Macau authorities estimate could pass within 100 kilometers of the territory. CNN indicated yesterday that, so far, this was the worst storm this year globally. Here, the arrival of the super typhoon led authorities to meet yesterday at the Civil Protection Operations Center with the Chief Executive. Sam Hoi Fai highlighted the importance of preventive work, noting that, based on analyzes by authorities in Mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, Ragasa could be the strongest storm to hit the Macao SAR since Mangkhut, a possibility he classified as “very high”. According to forecasts from the Meteorological and Geophysical Services, Ragasa could pass less than 100 kilometers from Macau between dawn and Wednesday morning. Sam Hou Fai understands that society and all government services must be alert, and should not just “have a mentality to count on good luck”. “It is often said that ‘Macau is a blessed land’, but this can result in negligence,” he added. The Chief Executive explained that Ragasa can cause overlapping “storm surge” phenomena, as occurred with Mangkhut, causing floods with a maximum height of five meters, at the level of the first floor of the Red Market, for example. "The impact could be significant. Preparation was carried out in advance and interdepartmental communication, hoping that the losses could be reduced to the minimum possible, in order to guarantee the safety and stability of the entire population. I seriously appeal to all traders, public and private institutions, and even associations, to do the preparation work against the catastrophe in advance", he warned. Casinos may close On the sidelines of the same meeting, the Secretary for Economy and Finance, Tai Kin Ip, said that casinos will close their doors if storm signal 8 is raised, and that authorities will broadcast this scenario in advance, in order to guarantee the personal safety of tourists and employees in the tourism sector. Wong Sio Chak, Secretary for Security, said that his department met with companies and associations to coordinate street cleaning efforts after the typhoon hit. The secretary also called for the evacuation, first of all, of older residents. In turn, the head of the Department of Family and Community Services at the Institute of Social Action, Lei Lai Peng, pointed out that the organization has prepared the launch of level 2 of the Emergency Evacuation and Reception Mechanism, with the 17 available emergency reception centers being able to be open, with the capacity to receive 24 thousand people. Regarding the Macau Bridge, Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, guaranteed that the infrastructure will be closed to traffic during the typhoon's passage, even though the previous results of tests on road traffic during storms were positive. The secretary justified the closure of the bridge by saying that Ragasa is a “super typhoon” and that he took into account the poor condition of access to the infrastructure. Raymond Tam also said that if the floods exceed one meter, he will consider the possibility of suspending the electricity supply in the lower areas of the territory, in order to speed up the entire recovery process after the typhoon. From 3pm this afternoon until tomorrow, between 250 and 280 flights to or from Macau International Airport will be cancelled. Regarding the return to school, the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, assured that the Government will analyze the situation based on official data on floods and intense rains that occurred after the typhoon, provided by the Meteorological and Geophysical Services. The condition of schools and roads will also be analyzed to decide whether there are conditions for reopening. However, O Lam indicated that schools have flexibility to address issues such as student attendance and testing scheduling.

item.title: DSAJ | Digital notary services launched
item.description: Digital notary services were launched yesterday by the Directorate of Justice Affairs Services (DSAJ), in a process that will be phased. According to a statement, the services concern four areas, namely deeds, endorsements, online requests for notary services and the provision of an electronic platform for registration requests to be used by private notaries. Yesterday, the 2nd Notary's Office launched the electronic deeds service, extending this service to the first notary's office, the Islands' Notary's Office and private notaries. According to DSAJ, this service “allows the collection, electronically, of the signatures of all grantors, in which the qualified electronic signature of the notary will be placed” in order to prevent “the tampering of documents and ensure their authenticity”. Also yesterday, the electronic endorsement service was launched “which applies to all electronic and paper deeds, as long as the respective digital images have been filed in the Notary System”. Next December, notary offices will begin accepting online requests for notary services, and residents can use the Macau Single Account platform to request services relating to purchase and sale deeds, or the creation of property mortgages, powers of attorney and authenticated documents (authentication terms). DSAJ also provides an online platform for private notaries to process land and commercial registration requests.

item.title: Macau | Portuguese folk dance registered as Intangible Cultural Heritage
item.description: Macau yesterday announced the inscription of 12 events, including Portuguese folk dance and local pastéis de nata, inspired by Portuguese pastel, on the List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of the semi-autonomous Chinese region. The registration was confirmed in an order, signed by the Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, dated September 26th, but which was only published today in the Macau Official Gazette. The territory's Intangible Cultural Heritage List now also includes the making of Jook-Sing pasta (a rare specialty made with duck eggs), almond cookies, traditional Chinese wedding cakes and cream puffs. Macau's custard tarts, inspired by the Portuguese pastry, were invented by a Brit living in the city, Andrew Stow (1955-2006). The list also includes the belief and customs of Tou Tei (the Chinese god of the Earth), the dragon boat festival and regatta, the dragon dance, the lion dance, the Spring Festival (which includes the Lunar New Year) and the martial art Tai Chi.

item.title: Women | Tina Ho talks about “golden period”
item.description: The permanent president of the General Women's Association, Tina Ho, considers that issues related to women in Macau are of increasing importance today, going through a “golden period” thanks to the principle of one country, two systems and the support granted by the Central Government since the territory's return to China. This idea appears in a statement released by the General Women's Association as part of the “Global Leaders on Women” meeting, which began yesterday and ends today, and where Tina Ho participated. At the event, this leader highlighted the fact that she has seen progress in change around women's issues over the last 30 years, concluding that Macau women are now more active in various areas, acting with more confidence and independently. In this way, Tina Ho considers that, currently, women in Macau are “important forces in driving the prosperity and progress of the Macao SAR”.

item.title: Companies | Internationalization seen as an opportunity
item.description: The secretary general of the Portuguese-Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry considered yesterday that the campaign for subsidies of up to 107 thousand euros for the internationalization of companies in Macau is “a great opportunity for Portuguese stores”. "It's a great opportunity for Portuguese stores that want to internationalize in Asia; Macau is a showcase for China and a place where tourists look for entertainment and shopping", said Bernardo Mendia, adding that "a good experience in Macau is a safe step towards later entering China". Speaking to Lusa, on the eve of the presentation of the program that will come into force in November, Bernardo Mendia explained that support of up to one million patacas, around 107 thousand euros, granted by the Chinese authorities, is for international companies that want to expand their presence to Macau, subject to certain conditions, which in the case of Portuguese and Spanish brands are mitigated. “If the companies are from Portuguese or Spanish-speaking countries, the requirements of the regulation are less stringent, as long as they are recommended by a chamber of commerce”, said the businessman, highlighting that, although the authorities' objective is to attract world-renowned brands to Macau, in the case of Portuguese and Spanish companies “the criteria for obtaining the subsidy is easier to comply with”. Furthermore, he highlighted, “in Macau there are Portuguese banks, legal services, accountants and other professional service providers essential to the internationalization of Portuguese brands”. The initiative will be presented today in Lisbon and, later, also in Porto, Madrid and Barcelona during this week, with the presence of officials from the Institute for the Promotion of Commerce and Investment (IPIM).
